
# Breast Cancer Text Mining Julia 

## Introduction
Breast cancer is the most common type of cancer diagnosed among women and is the second leading cause of cancer death. 3
Approximately 252,710 new cases of invasive breast cancer and 63,410 cases of in situ breast carcinoma were expected to be diagnosed among US women in 2017, and 40,610 women are expected to die from this disease alone.3 Overall, breast cancer mortality rates have decreased by 39%...

## Analysis
Text mining can be used to discover these knowledge patterns or hypotheses in helping to solve biomedical questions. We will perform 3 analysis i.e on treatment, diagnosis and prevention

### Diagnosis
Starting by creating a dataframe of diagnosis metadata and text for the year 2008 to  2018. i.e search using medline and fetch full artcile from PMC (pubmed central) and store it as dataframe


```julia

df_full_text = @time bcTextmining.searchAndFetchFullArtcles("breast neoplasms","diagnosis",2008, 2018,100, true)

# # display all field except df_full_text 
df_full_text[:, filter(x -> x != :fullText, names(df_full_text))]
```

2  However  no associations with\\nclinicopathological parameters such as tumour size  tumour type\\nor lymph node status were found  Moreover  nuclear expression of\\nSnail was inversely correlated to expression of both the ERa\\n\\n P¼ 0 002  and the PR  P¼ 0 006   Table 2  No correlation was\\nobserved between Snail expression and HIF-1a  but a positive\\ncorrelation to expression of the hypoxia marker CAIX  P¼ 0 040 \\nwas found  suggesting a possible link between EMT and hypoxia in\\nbreast cancer  Table 2  Notably  cytoplasmic Snail expression was\\nnot associated with any of the variables described  We examined\\nrecurrence-free survival among patients in the untreated control\\ngroup according to Snail expression  however  Snail expression\\nhad no prognostic value  Figure 5A  Survival analyses revealed a\\ntrend towards impaired tamoxifen response among patients with\\nSnail-negative tumours  compared with the those having Snail-\\npositive tumours  Figure 5B and C  Interestingly  when analysing\\npatients randomised to tamoxifen treatment vs no adjuvant\\ntreatment  using a multivariate Cox proportional-hazards regres-\\nsion model for Snail and treatment interaction  a statistically\\nsignificant difference between the two subgroups defined by\\nnuclear Snail expression was observed  P¼ 0 048   Table 3  These\\nresults indicate that patients with tumours exhibiting no nuclear\\nSnail expression are less likely to respond to tamoxifen  as\\ncompared with patients with Snail-positive tumours \\n\\nHypoxic cells of DCIS express nuclear Snail\\n\\nWe continued by investigating the expression of Snail in a model\\nsystem of hypoxia in vivo  non-invasive DCIS  DCIS lesions are\\noften presented with areas of central necrosis where hypoxic\\ntumour cells are surrounding the necrotic zone  Our aim was to\\nelucidate whether these hypoxic cells displayed an EMT pheno-\\ntype  Hypoxia-inducible factor-1a staining of full sections of DCIS\\nconfirmed the presence of hypoxia in cell layers adjacent to the\\ncentral necrosis  Staining intensity and number of HIF-1a-positive\\ncells however  varied noticeably between samples and lesions \\nsuggesting antibody unreliability  The typical HIF-1a expression\\npattern that distinguishes DCIS is shown in Figure 6A  Helczynska\\net al  2003  Cytoplasmic Snail expression was present in the\\nmajority of cells  whereas nuclear expression gradually increased\\napproaching the necrosis  in a number of DCIS samples\\n Figure 6B and C  However  E-cadherin and vimentin expression\\nwas not changed in close proximity of the central necrosis  data\\nnot shown  Hence  DCIS did not display EMT-like features  but\\nthe results again confirmed that hypoxia induces Snail expression \\nand that this induction does not necessarily affect other EMT\\nmarkers \\n\\n50  m 50  m\\n\\nFigure 4 Expression of Snail in primary breast tumours   A  Tumour core exhibiting absence of Snail different consensus motifs  the first resulting\\nin targeting Snail for ubiquitination and the second regulating its\\nsubcellular localisation  A Snail mutant exhibiting mutations in\\nthese phosphorylation motifs was shown to be much more stable\\nand resided exclusively in the nucleus  suggesting that only Snail\\nthat is unable to interact with and become phosphorylated by GSK-\\n3b is able to induce EMT in breast cancer cells  Interestingly  when\\nscreening for mutations in the two consensus motifs of Snail  no\\nmutations could be identified  indicating that the upstream\\nsignalling is the crucial mechanism determining the function of\\nSnail  Another protein that regulates the activity of Snail is the p21-\\nactivated kinase 1  Pak1   Yang et al  2005  Pak1 phosphorylation\\nof Snail promotes nuclear accumulation and transcription repres-\\nsion activity of the E-cadherin gene in breast cancer cells  and\\nhence induction of EMT  Yang et al  2005  However  further\\nstudies are required to delineate the mechanism underlying\\nnuclear  cytoplasmic shuttling and subcellular localisation of Snail \\n\\nIn the present study we demonstrated that subcellular localisa-\\ntion of Snail changes over time in breast cancer cell lines exposed\\nto hypoxia  In MCF-7 cells E-cadherin was hardly detectable after\\n72 h  and expression of nuclear Snail was concurrently elevated \\nindicating that at this time point Snail was actively repressing\\nE-cadherin-gene transcription in this cell line  Similarly  in MDA-\\nMB-468 and MDA-MB-231 cells nuclear expression levels of Snail\\npeaked at 96 h  around the same time that vimentin expression\\nlevels were markedly elevated in both cell lines  Nuclear expression\\nof Snail did not increase as prominently in T-47D cells as in the\\nother cell lines  which might explain the maintained levels of\\nE-cadherin observed for this cell line  Our results indicate that\\nhypoxia induces the expression of Snail  and after longer exposure\\nSnail localises to the nucleus and exerts its EMT-inducing\\nfunctions  resulting in downregulation of E-cadherin and upregu-\\nlation of vimentin levels  The net result differs between cell lines \\nsuggesting Snail to be more important as a regulator of EMT in\\nsome contexts  and may be inferior to other EMT regulators such\\nas Slug or Twist in others \\n\\nThe ‘EMT status’ of a cell line may not affect EMT regulation \\nthat is  overexpression of Snail can induce a more migratory\\nphenotype in both low-migratory  epithelial-like cell lines and in\\nhighly migratory  mesenchymal-like cell lines  The fact that Snail\\noverexpression increased the migratory ability of both MCF-7\\nand T-47D cells  despite maintenance of E-cadherin expression in\\nT-47D cells  suggests that E-cadherin expression does not exclude\\na migratory behaviour  The highly migratory MDA-MB-231 cells\\nfurther increased their migratory capacity when overexpressing\\nSnail  without exhibiting increased vimentin levels  further\\nimplying that Snail itself can drive migration independently of\\nan EMT induction  Knocking down Snail resulted in significant\\nreduction of the migratory capacity of MCF-7  MDA-MB-468 and\\nMDA-MB-231 cells  The mechanism behind this shift in migration\\ncan again not be explained by regulation of E-cadherin or\\nvimentin  since expression of neither of the two proteins was\\nsignificantly changed by Snail silencing  Hence  another regulator\\nof cell migration dependent or independent of EMT is possibly\\naffected by Snail depletion  A plethora of factors play roles in the\\ninduction of EMT and regulating mechanisms generally differ\\nbetween cell lines \\n\\nA number of studies describing Snail in breast cancer have been\\npublished  and the critical findings differ slightly among them  In\\none study Snail immunoreactivity was observed exclusively in the\\ncytoplasm  contrasting to what is generally observed  Zhou et al \\n2004  indicating antibody unreliability in this field of research \\nBecker et al  2007  reported 33% of breast cancers as being\\npositive for nuclear Snail staining  similar to the 31% that we\\nobserved  using the same Snail antibody as in our study  Presence\\nof nuclear Snail predicted a tumour phenotype displaying a more\\npoorly differentiated histology and increased proliferation rate in\\npremenopausal breast cancer  confirming the previously reported\\n\\nlink between EMT and clinical aggressiveness  Cano et al  2000 \\nBlanco et al  2002  Additionally  nuclear Snail protein was\\nassociated with more extensive hypoxia  defined by expression of\\nthe HIF-1a-inducible gene CAIX  Chaudary and Hill  2006 \\nimplying a link between hypoxia and EMT in primary breast\\ncancer  However  no correlation between Snail and HIF-1a\\nexpression was observed  Cytoplasmic Snail expression was not\\nassociated with HIF-1a or CAIX  or with any other clinicopatho-\\nlogical variables  suggesting that expression of nuclear Snail plays\\nthe main role in determining the extent of clinical aggressiveness\\nin breast cancer  A negative correlation between nuclear Snail and\\npresence of ERa was observed  and this inverse relationship has\\npreviously been reported with a number of breast tumour\\nmaterials analysed by microarray  Dhasarathy et al  2007 \\nMoreover  Snail has been reported to directly repress ERa-gene\\ntranscription in MCF-7 cells by binding to the promoter region\\n Dhasarathy et al  2007  The ER–MTA3–E-cadherin pathway has\\nemerged as a novel pathway in the regulation of ER signalling  and\\nallelic alterations in these genes have been reported to be\\nassociated with both tumour-promoting and antitumour mechan-\\nisms  Cheng et al  2001  Fearon  2003  Furthermore  Snail\\nsuppresses the expression of the oestrogen-converting enzyme\\naromatase  Kumar  2003  resulting in reduced levels of peripheral\\noestrogen converted from adipose tissue  which should be\\nprotective against breast cancer  The molecular function of Snail\\nin breast epithelium is intricate and is further complicated by\\ninteraction with its downstream targets  such as the ER  Moreover \\naetiological factors such as  for example  age at first full-term\\npregnancy  affects the importance of Snail as a susceptibility\\nmarker  and single-nucleotide polymorphism  SNP  of Snail has\\nbeen shown to be of importance for the oestrogen-related risk\\nfactor in relation to breast cancer risk  Yu et al  2006  In one study\\nit was demonstrated that 17b-estradiol  E2  treatment  in an ERa\\nmediated manner  resulted in increased metastatic potential \\nmorphological changes characteristic of EMT and increased\\ntranscriptional activity of the Snail and Slug genes  accompanied\\nby decreased levels of E-cadherin in an ovarian cancer cell line\\n Park et al  2008  Silencing of either Snail or Slug caused reversion\\nof the mesenchymal-like phenotype  and in addition treatment\\nwith the oestrogen antagonist ICI was shown to overcome the\\ninhibitory effect of E2 on E-cadherin transcription  suggesting a\\ncrucial role for oestrogen and its receptor in EMT-dependent\\ntumour progression  Interestingly  in the same study it was also\\ndemonstrated that presence of ERb had an opposing effect on ERa \\nin the context of EMT regulation  inhibiting the ERa-induced EMT\\n Park et al  2008  These findings may explain the mechanism by\\nwhich ER status regulates invasion and metastasis in breast cancer \\nNevertheless  the effect of oestrogen and the role of ER in the\\ncontext of Snail and EMT regulation remain elusive  The fact that\\npatients with Snail-negative tumours exhibited impaired tamoxifen\\nresponse  as compared with treated patients with Snail-positive\\ntumours in our study  is intriguing  but the underlying mechanism\\nis yet to be elucidated  Speculatively  Snail may affect the function\\nof ERa in a way that potentiates the effect of the ER antagonist\\ntamoxifen  In tumours with nuclear Snail expression  tamoxifen\\nmight exert its effect by inhibiting the function of Snail  as\\ndescribed previously for the antagonist ICI  This in turn may lead\\nto a less invasive tumour phenotype  since EMT is reverted  In\\nSnail-negative tumours tamoxifen would not be able to exert the\\nsame mechanistic effect  resulting in an abolished response \\nExpression of ERb may also influence the mechanism that renders\\npatients with Snail-negative tumours non-responsive to tamoxifen \\nEvidently  further studies including large randomised clinical\\ncohorts are needed to investigate the role of Snail as a treatment\\npredictive in tumorigenic behaviour of breast cancer cell lines  and its\\nassociation with clinicopathological parameters defining a more\\naggressive tumour phenotype  We demonstrate that breast cancer\\ncells can enter a hybrid state of EMT  which is distinguished by\\npartial mesenchymal conversion  where some hallmarks of EMT\\nare present and others absent  Loss of E-cadherin expression is\\na well-established definition of invasiveness  Mayer et al  1993 \\nOka et al  1993  It has  however  been debated whether this\\ndefinition is reliable or not  Christiansen and Rajasekaran  2006 \\nThe expression of E-cadherin was reported in one study to be\\npresent in the majority of invasive breast carcinomas examined\\n Hashizume et al  1996  Furthermore  node-negative and node-\\npositive tumours exhibited similar E-cadherin expression and no\\ncorrelation between E-cadherin expression and metastatic status\\nwas observed  A number of additional reports show similar results\\nregarding E-cadherin expression and tumour aggressiveness  imply-\\ning that invasion is not necessarily dependent on a complete\\ntransition to a mesenchymal phenotype  Parker et al  2001  Kovacs\\net al  2003  Barrallo-Gimeno and co-workers argued that the\\nprimary function of Snail is to enhance cell movement  rather than\\nto induce EMT  Barrallo-Gimeno and Nieto  2005  In addition \\n\\nLou et al  2008  reported that the metastatic ability was not linked\\nto the EMT status  A cell line with expression of vimentin and lack\\nof E-cadherin expression was unable to metastasise  whereas\\nanother cell line exhibiting epithelial characteristics was capable of\\nmetastasising  Accordingly  the question if a primary tumour will\\nmetastasise or not may not be determined by the EMT phenotype\\nof the tumour cells  The expression of Snail itself may hold more\\ninformation about a tumour’s invasive capacity and ability to\\nmetastasise than the actual EMT status \\n\\nACKNOWLEDGEMENTS\\n\\nWe thank \\n\\nIntroduction\\nRecent data from neoadjuvant studies  predominantly for\\nendocrine therapy but also for chemotherapy  indicate that a\\nsingle measurement of the nuclear proliferation marker Ki67\\nmade in the breast carcinoma during/after neoadjuvant\\ntherapy is strongly predictive of long-term disease outcome \\nIn an era when many mega-parameter signatures have been\\nderived with the aim of improving the accuracy of prediction \\nit is superficially very surprising that a single immunohisto-\\nchemical measurement can act in this fashion  This provokes\\na number of questions  and the following three are\\naddressed below  What is the underlying reason for this\\npredictive ability  Given that Ki67 is influenced by\\ntreatment/external factors and is not stable in the short term \\nwhy does it predict in the long term  What is the best time\\nfor measuring Ki67 \\n\\nThe data\\nKi67 is relatively straightforward to measure in formalin-fixed\\ntissue  being clearly expressed in the nuclei of cells that are\\nactively proliferating  The MIB1 antibody has been a preferred\\ndiagnostic for many years  but the relatively new antibody\\nSP6 is now our choice because of its more straightforward\\napplicability to image analysis [1] \\n\\nThe IMPACT  Immediate Preoperative Arimidex  tamoxifen  or\\nCombined with Tamoxifen  neoadjuvant trial of anastrozole\\nversus tamoxifen alone or combined reported that reduction\\nin Ki67 at 2 weeks and 12 weeks was greater for the\\nanastrazole alone arm than for either of the other two arms \\nmimicking the greater clinical benefit  in terms of increased\\nrecurrence-free survival  RFS  seen in the equivalent\\nadjuvant ATAC  Arimidex  Tamoxifen  Alone or in Combina-\\ntion  trial [2]  Most importantly  follow-up of these patients\\n\\nindicated that the Ki67 level at 2 weeks was a better\\npredictor of RFS than pretreatment levels  to the degree that \\nin a multivariate model  the 2-week value of Ki67 remained\\nstatistically significant but the pretreatment value was no\\nlonger significant [3] \\n\\nSimilar data at the end of neoadjuvant treatment have been\\npublished for letrozole and tamoxifen in the PO24 trial [4] \\nThese data are important firstly because they add further\\nvalidity to changing Ki67 at 2 weeks being an intermediate\\nmarker of effectiveness  thereby supporting the use of this\\nmarker for drug development and studies of mechanisms of\\nresistance  Secondly  the data indicate that prognostic\\nevaluation with Ki67 may be better after presurgical therapy \\nLastly  this observation may extend beyond Ki67 such that\\nmultiparameter profiling may be of greater value if conducted\\nin on-treatment samples \\n\\nThese data have underpinned the development of the\\nrecently launched POETIC  Peri Operative Endocrine Treat-\\nment for Individualising Care CRUK number CRUK/07/015 \\ntrial of the presurgical use or not of a nonsteroidal aromatase\\ninhibitor in 4 000 oestrogen receptor-positive breast cancer\\npatients  This study should provide very good power to\\nevaluate the importance of Ki67 on-treatment to predicting\\nlong-term clinical outcome \\n\\nA particularly striking set of data has been derived from our\\nstudies of a single measurement of Ki67 after neoadjuvant\\nchemotherapy in patients not achieving a pathological\\ncomplete remission  Patients in the highest tertile of Ki67 in\\nthe residual tissue at surgery had a median RFS of only about\\n18 months  while in the lower two tertiles the median RFS\\nwas not reached after 7 years [5] \\n\\nShort communication\\nWho would have thought a single Ki67 measurement would\\npredict long-term outcome \\nMitch Dowsett1 2  Roger A’Hern3 Research 2009  11 Suppl 3 S15\\nThis article is online at  doi 10 1186/bcr2434 \\nhttp //breast-cancer-research com/supplements/11/S3/S15 © 2009 BioMed Central Ltd\\n\\nRFS = recurrence-free survival \\n\\n\\n\\nBreast Cancer Research    Vol 11 Suppl 3 Dowsett et al \\n\\nPage 2 of 2\\n page number not for citation purposes \\n\\nWhat is the underlying reason for the\\nprediction provided by on-treatment Ki67 \\nFirstly  it is notable that Ki67 at baseline is a highly prognostic\\nfactor in breast cancer [6]  Many studies confirm that\\nproliferation is a dominant feature of multigene signatures in\\nbreast cancer  For example  in a study of seven molecular\\nmodules and clinical variables in 628 oestrogen receptor-\\npositive  HER2-negative breast tumours from public data-\\nbases  Desmedt and colleagues found that only the prolifera-\\ntion module  P <10–11  and the grade  P = 0 01  were\\nsignificant in multivariate analysis [7] \\n\\nSecondly  it is clear that the suppression of Ki67 by endo-\\ncrine treatment is profound but variable between patients \\napparently reflecting the variable biological impact of oestro-\\ngen deprivation  These variable changes result in a pattern of\\non-treatment Ki67 in which patients with low Ki67 at baseline\\nlargely maintain this low proliferation but patients with higher\\nlevels may or may not show suppression to that level \\n\\nIf these changes were associated with the variable impact of\\na treatment with modest clinical effects  it is unlikely that the\\non-treatment measurements would be of much greater value\\nthan those at baseline  It is clear from studies such as the\\nOxford overview analysis [8] and recent adjuvant trials of\\naromatase inhibitors versus tamoxifen [9] that the impact of\\nthese treatments in the overall population is very substantial \\nhowever  with the recurrent rate being estimated to be\\nreduced by an aromatase inhibitor in oestrogen receptor-\\npositive patients by approximately 50% over the first 5 years \\n\\nWhen is the best time to measure Ki67 \\nThe change in Ki67 values over the first 2 weeks is highly\\ncorrelated with changes that occur at 12 weeks after starting\\nneoadjuvant endocrine therapy  A recent  unpublished \\ncomparison from the IMPACT trial of RFS at 2 weeks or\\n12 weeks in patients who have both measurements available\\nfound that  when assessed as a continuous variable  there was\\nnear identical prediction provided by each measurement\\n χ2 = 11 5 and χ2 = 11 8 at 2 weeks and 12 weeks \\nrespectively  It is notable nonetheless that some patients do\\nshow recovery of Ki67 between 2 and 12 weeks  That this\\nrecovery is likely to be meaningful is supported by the latter\\npopulation being enriched with HER2-positive patients \\nFurther work to establish whether this population has a worse\\nRFS than patients showing persistent Ki67 response at\\n12 weeks is important to allow the extension of the\\nneoadjuvant model to the study of early acquired resistance \\nboth for the purpose of mechanism study and for development\\nof therapeutics \\n\\nSummary and conclusions\\nIf one is interested in assessing prognosis with no account\\nbeing taken of the effects of treatment  it would appear that\\nthe most appropriate time to measure Ki67 is at baseline  If \\nhowever  one is interested in also considering the long-term\\n\\noutcome on a particular endocrine treatment  measurement at\\n2 weeks or at 12 weeks appears to be of similar value  No\\naccount of pretreatment value is needed in these circum-\\nstances  If the response of the tumour to a particular\\ntreatment is being evaluated  however  then it is the change\\nbetween the baseline and an on-treatment value that is\\nrelevant  A single on-treatment measurement is insufficient for\\nidentifying benefit  Lastly  if one is interested in assessing\\nonly acquired resistance  the change between 2 weeks and a\\nlater time point of at least 12 weeks is needed for the early\\nrecovery of Ki67 levels \\n\\nCompeting interests\\nMD receives paid advisory boards and research funding from\\neach of Novartis  AstraZeneca and Roche value remains debated\\n\\n[9  10] \\n\\nThe stem cell-like phenotype of tumor-initiating cells\\n\\nand their limited number within the bulk of a tumor may\\n\\naccount for their ability to escape conventional therapies \\n\\nleading to disease relapse although the primary lesion has\\n\\nbeen removed [11]  In breast cancer  Al-Hajj et al  [12]\\n\\nwere the first to isolate a highly tumorigenic subpopulation\\n\\nof tumor cells with the CD44 /CD24- phenotype  They\\n\\ndemonstrated that CD44 /CD24- tumor cells resembled\\n\\nnormal stem/progenitor cells with respect to their ability to\\n\\nself-renew  proliferate  and differentiate [11]  Although\\n\\nonly one-third of human breast cancers have the CD44 /\\n\\nCD24- phenotype  this tumor cell population appears most\\n\\ncommonly in TNBC [13] \\n\\nResearch on the correlation between EGFR expression\\n\\nand CD44/CD24 and their prognostic value in breast\\n\\ninvasive ductal carcinoma  BIDC  is limited  In this study \\n\\nwe aimed to evaluate the correlation between EGFR\\n\\nexpression and CD44/CD24 and determine their relation-\\n\\nship with BIDC clinicopathological parameters and \\n\\nDiscussion\\n\\nIDC is the most common type of breast cancer  BIDC can\\n\\nbe divided into triple-negative and non-triple-negative\\n\\nbased on the hormone receptor status  TNBC accounts for\\n\\n10–17 % of all breast cancers [15]  As we studied IDC in\\n\\nthe present study  TNBC only accounted for 8 5 % of all\\n\\nbreast cancers \\n\\nTNBC is relatively large  high grade  has a high rate of\\n\\nnode positivity at diagnosis  and is biologically more\\n\\naggressive  Despite the higher rates of clinical response to\\n\\nneoadjuvant chemotherapy  TNBC patients have a higher\\n\\nrate of distant recurrence and poorer prognosis compared\\n\\nwith patients with other breast cancer subtypes [2  3] \\n\\nConsistent with the literature  our findings demonstrated\\n\\nthat TNBC patients had significantly worse DFS and OS\\n\\ncompared with non-TNBC patients  Fig  2a  e \\n\\nEGFR is expressed in all types of breast cancer  espe-\\n\\ncially in TNBC [5  16]  EGFR was first reported as a sig-\\n\\nnificant prognostic factor in breast cancer by Sainsbury\\n\\nFig  3 In node-negative\\npatients  EGFR-positive patients\\n\\nDFS and OS were significantly\\n\\nlower than EGFR-negative\\n\\npatients  a  b    CD44- and\\nCD24-positive both showed a\\n\\nsignificant negative correlation\\n\\nwith OS  c  e \\n\\n275 Page 6 of 11 Med Oncol  2015  32 275\\n\\n123\\n\\n\\n\\net al  [17]  Since then  many researchers have reported\\n\\ndiffering findings on the prognostic value of EGFR in\\n\\nbreast cancer  and there is still no agreement on the rela-\\n\\ntionship between EGFR and clinical outcome [18  19]  In\\n\\nthe present study  EGFR expression was inversely corre-\\n\\nlated with ER status  p = 0 023  Although EGFR was\\n\\nfrequently expressed in TNBC  there was no statistically\\n\\nsignificant difference between TNBC and non-TNBC\\n\\npatients  p = 0 108  EGFR-positive patients were more\\n\\nlikely to develop distant metastases  p = 0 018  which\\n\\nindicated that EGFR may be an important prognostic factor\\n\\nfor distant metastasis  Survival analysis showed that EGFR\\n\\npositive indicated significantly shorter survival time in the\\n\\nlymph node- and HR-negative group  These data strongly\\n\\nindicate that EGFR-positive status is related to breast\\n\\ncancer progression and is a pivotal prognostic factor for\\n\\nspecific subgroup \\n\\nAlthough EGFR-positive status is correlated with poor\\n\\nclinical prognosis  Tang et al  [20] found that EGFR\\n\\noverexpression predicted better response to neoadjuvant\\n\\nchemotherapy in patients with TNBC  This is a possible\\n\\nreason that TNBC is more chemosensitive \\n\\nNumerous studies have reported that CD44 /CD24-\\n\\nepithelial tumor cells are the most common in TNBC [14 \\n\\n21  22]  but the relationship between CD44 /CD24- cells\\n\\nand prognosis in breast cancer is debated  Lee et al \\n\\nreported that a high proportion of CD44 /CD24- tumor\\n\\ncells in prechemotherapy tissue was correlated with higher\\n\\nFig  4 In node-positive\\npatients  EGFR  a  b  CD44  c \\nd  and CD24  e  f  did not show\\na significant relationship with\\n\\nthe OS and DFS\\n\\nMed Oncol  2015  32 275 Page 7 of 11 275\\n\\n123\\n\\n\\n\\nhistological grade  ER negativity  and high Ki-67 prolif-\\n\\neration index  After primary systemic therapy  the pro-\\n\\nportions of CD44 /CD24- tumor cells were significantly\\n\\nincreased [23]  Wu et al  [14] demonstrated that the\\n\\nCD44 /CD24- and CD24 /CD44- phenotypes associ-\\n\\nated with decreased DFS but were not independent pre-\\n\\ndictors for DFS  Giatromanolaki et al  [22] reported that\\n\\nthe CD44 /CD24- and CD44-/CD24- phenotypes\\n\\nindicated unfavorable prognosis in TNBC  However  Kim\\n\\nand colleagues reported that the CD44 /CD24- group is\\n\\nconsidered a favorable prognostic subgroup in breast\\n\\ncancer  CD24 expression was a poor prognostic marker in\\n\\nHR-positive breast cancer  and CD44 expression was a\\n\\ngood prognostic marker in the HR-negative group [24] \\n\\nAnother study showed that there was no correlation\\n\\nbetween the CD44 /CD24- phenotype and outcome in\\n\\nHR-positive breast cancer [25]  In the present study  76 9\\n\\nand 50 % of TNBC and non-TNBC patients  respectively \\n\\nshowed positive CD44 expression  p \\ 0 05  However \\nCD24 did not show statistically different expression levels\\n\\nbetween the two groups  p = 0 131  CD44-positive\\n\\nexpression was inversely associated with HER2-positive\\n\\nstatus and HR-positive status  while CD24-positive\\n\\nexpression was correlated with HER2-positive status but\\n\\nhad nothing to do with HR-positive status  This study\\n\\nshowed that CD44 positive was significantly correlated\\n\\nwith survival time only in lymph node- and HR-negative\\n\\npatients while CD24 positive was significantly correlated\\n\\nwith survival time in lymph node-negative and HR-posi-\\n\\ntive patients \\n\\nFig  5 In HR  hormone\\nreceptor  negative patients \\n\\nEGFR- a  b  and CD44- c \\nd  positive patients both\\nexperienced shorter OS and\\n\\nDFS\\n\\n275 Page 8 of 11 Med Oncol  2015  32 275\\n\\n123\\n\\n\\n\\nAlthough the rate of EGFR expression is high in breast\\n\\ncancer  especially in TNBC  EGFR inhibitors do not have\\n\\nan ideal curative effect in breast cancer  Previous studies\\n\\nhave suggested that synthetic lethal cross-linking of\\n\\ninhibitors of the mitogen-activated protein kinase  MAPK \\n\\nkinase  MEK /MAPK pathway  EGFR  and poly ADP-\\n\\nribosyl  transferase  PARP  may be related [26  27]  In this\\n\\nstudy  EGFR and CD44 expressions were significantly\\n\\npositively correlated  p = 0 017  The CD44 /CD24-\\n\\ntumor cell phenotype is recognized as a cancer stem cell\\n\\ncharacteristic [11]  It is believed that CD44 /CD24-\\n\\nbreast cancer cells are highly invasive and radioresistant\\n\\nand chemoresistant [28]  The close correlation between\\n\\nCD44 and EGFR expressions may be another reason for the\\n\\nresistance to EGFR inhibitors in breast cancer  Combining\\n\\nEGFR inhibitors with CD44 inhibitors may be a novel\\n\\nmethod for breast cancer treatment  especially TNBC \\n\\nIn conclusion  our study indicates that in combination \\n\\nEGFR and CD44/CD24 expression status are powerful\\n\\nidentifiers of breast cancer patient subgroups with dif-\\n\\nferent clinical behavior  Although our study has some\\n\\nlimitations  such as its retrospective design and relatively\\n\\nsmall number of studied patients  the data obtained\\n\\nindicate that EGFR and CD44 could serve as useful\\n\\nbiomarkers for better determination of the prognosis of\\n\\ninvasive breast cancer  These findings may have thera-\\n\\npeutic significance and may improve the management of\\n\\nbreast cancer patients Health § Medical School \\n\\nUniversity of Liverpool  Liverpool  and Royal Bolton Hospital ¶\\n\\nBolton  United Kingdom\\n\\nThe secreted metastasis-inducing protein  human an-\\nterior gradient 2  AGR2  has been independently re-\\nported to be associated with either a reduced or an\\nincreased survival of different groups of patients with\\nbreast cancer  We now aim to analyze the expression\\nof AGR2 in a third completely independent group of\\npatients using a specific AGR2 monoclonal antibody\\n mAb  Primary tumors from a group of 315 patients\\nsuffering from operable  stage I and II  breast cancer\\nwith 20-years follow-up were immunocytochemically\\nstained with a specific mAb to AGR2 and associations\\nwith prognostic factors and patient survival were an-\\nalyzed  The mAb specifically recognized AGR2 in\\nWestern blots  and positive staining for AGR2 was\\nsignificantly associated with involved lymph nodes\\nand staining for estrogen receptor     progesterone\\nreceptor  and the metastasis-inducing proteins os-\\nteopontin  S100P  and S100A4  After 20 years of fol-\\nlow-up  only 26% of patients with AGR2-positive car-\\ncinomas survived compared with 96% of those with\\nAGR2 negative carcinomas  with the highly signifi-\\ncant difference in median survival times of 68 and\\n>216 months  respectively  P < 0 0001  Cox’s multi-\\nvariate regression analysis showed that staining for\\nAGR2 was one of the most significant independent prog-\\nnostic indicators  with a corrected relative risk of 9 4  The\\npresence of AGR2 in the primary tumor is therefore a\\npossible prognostic indicator of poor patient outcome in\\nbreast cancer   Am J Pathol 2009  175 1848–1857  DOI \\n10 2353/ajpath 2009 090246 \\n\\nAnterior gradient 2  AGR2  protein is a secreted protein\\nfirst described in Xenopus laevis embryos  where it in-\\nduces the formation of the forebrain and the mucus-\\nsecreting cement gland 1 Human AGR2 is also found\\nco-expressed with estrogen receptor    ER   in breast\\ncancer cell lines2 and its presence significantly corre-\\nlates with ER  in breast carcinoma specimens 3 Subse-\\nquent studies have found elevated expression of AGR2 in\\nadenocarcinomas of the esophagus  pancreas  prostate \\nand non-small cell lung cancer  showing that it is a widely\\noverexpressed protein in human carcinomas 4–10 We\\nhave shown that human AGR2 is expressed at higher\\nlevels in malignant  rather than in benign breast tumors 11\\n\\nand that  when introduced in an expression vector into\\nthe benign  nonmetastatic rat mammary cell line  Rama\\n37 12 it causes metastasis in syngeneic rats 11 These\\nresults suggest that AGR2’s metastasis-inducing proper-\\nties may contribute toward the malignant progression of\\nsome breast cancers  Certain molecules shown to induce\\nmetastasis in experimental breast cancer in rodents  for\\nexample  S100A4  S100P  and osteopontin  OPN 13–16\\n\\nprovide a potential source for markers that may be useful\\nas prognostic factors in predicting patient outcome in\\nhuman breast cancer \\n\\nSupported by Cancer and Polio Research Fund patients with ER -positive breast cancers after\\ntreatment with antiestrogen therapy 17 In contrast to\\nthese results  it has been reported that in another panel of\\n155 breast carcinoma patients treated with various adju-\\nvant therapies  immunocytochemically detected AGR2 in\\nthe cancer cells was associated with significantly longer\\npatient survival times  although there was still a signifi-\\ncant correlation with the presence of ER  and lower\\ntumor grade 18 To resolve these apparent conflicting as-\\nsociations of AGR2 protein with patient survival  the ex-\\npression of immunocytochemically detectable AGR2 pro-\\ntein has now been determined in the primary tumors of an\\nindependent group of 315 patients suffering from opera-\\nble breast cancer and treated by surgery alone with no\\naccompanying adjuvant therapy  A new specific mono-\\nclonal antibody  mAb  to AGR2  which does not cross-\\nreact with the closely-related AGR3 protein 3 has been\\nused to improve the accuracy of detection of AGR2  The\\nresults show that  in this large group of breast cancer\\npatients  the presence of immunocytochemically detect-\\nable AGR2 protein in the primary tumor is strongly asso-\\nciated with a reduced survival of the corresponding\\npatients \\n\\nMaterials and Methods\\n\\nPatients and Specimens\\n\\nArchival paraffin-embedded specimens were can-\\ncer cell lines 2 11 like OPN 30 consistent with its coordi-\\nnated appearance with ER   PgR  and pS2 in the human\\nbreast cancer specimens reported here  and its suppres-\\nsion in primary induced independently  in concert with OPN \\nby physiological stress  including oxygen deprivation 32\\n\\nIn cultured cells it can induce cell migration  anchorage\\nindependent growth and increase tumorigenicity in nude\\nmice 33 and increase cell attachment and induce metas-\\ntasis in syngenic rats11 without increasing rates of cell\\nproliferation 11 33 in line with the other three metastasis-\\ninducing proteins 29 28 16 The relatively coordinated over-\\nproduction of four proteins that can induce metastasis in\\na rat mammary model has now identified a new subgroup\\nof breast cancer patients with a poor outcome  Since\\nAGR2 is also secreted 11 33 and it can inhibit the p53\\ndependent response to DNA damage4 and its mRNA is\\nfound in circulating tumor cells 6 it is a good candidate for\\nuse as a prognostic test34 for likely patient outcome in\\nbreast and potentially other adenocarcinomas 4 5 8 More-\\nover  since the mAb used for staining for AGR2 has a\\nhigher discriminatory ability between those patients who\\nsurvive and those who will die from metastatic disease  it\\nmay be more appropriate for this purpose than the PAb\\nalready published 17 Inducing\\nWnt Co-Receptor LRP6 Degradation and Inhibiting the\\nWnt/b-Catenin Pathway\\nWenyan Lu1  Cuihong Lin1  Michael J  Roberts2  William R  Waud3  Gary A  Piazza4  Yonghe Li1*\\n\\n1Drug Birmingham  Alabama  United States of America  4Mitchell Cancer Institute  University of South\\n\\nAlabama  Mobile  Alabama  United States of America\\n\\nAbstract\\n\\nThe Wnt/b-catenin signaling pathway is important for tumor initiation and progression  The low density lipoprotein\\nreceptor-related protein-6  LRP6  is an essential Wnt co-receptor for Wnt/b-catenin signaling and represents a promising\\nanticancer target  Recently  the antihelminthic drug  niclosamide was found to inhibit Wnt/b-catenin signaling  although the\\nmechanism was not well defined  We found that niclosamide was able to suppress LRP6 expression and phosphorylation \\nblock Wnt3A-induced b-catenin accumulation  and inhibit Wnt/b-catenin signaling in HEK293 cells  Furthermore  the\\ninhibitory effects of niclosamide on LRP6 expression/phosphorylation and Wnt/b-catenin signaling were conformed in\\nhuman prostate PC-3 and DU145 and breast MDA-MB-231 and T-47D cancer cells  Moreover  we showed that the\\nmechanism by which niclosamide suppressed LRP6 resulted from increased degradation as evident by a shorter half-life \\nFinally  we demonstrated that niclosamide was able to induce cancer cell apoptosis  and displayed excellent anticancer\\nactivity with IC50 values less than 1 mM for prostate PC-3 and DU145 and breast MDA-MB-231 and T-47D cancer cells  The\\nIC50 values are comparable to those shown to suppress the activities of Wnt/b-catenin signaling in prostate and breast\\ncancer cells  Our data indicate that niclosamide is a unique small molecule Wnt/b-catenin signaling inhibitor targeting the\\nWnt co-receptor LRP6 on the cell surface  and that niclosamide has a potential to be developed a novel chemopreventive or\\ntherapeutic agent for human prostate and breast cancer competing interests exist \\n\\n* E-mail  y li@southernresearch org\\n\\nIntroduction\\n\\nWnt/b-catenin signaling plays an important role in embryonic\\ndevelopment and can lead to tumor formation when aberrantly\\n\\nactivated  A hallmark of the Wnt/b-catenin signaling activation is\\nthe stabilization of cytosolic b-catenin  which enters the nucleus to\\nactivate Wnt target genes by binding transcription factors of the T-\\n\\ncell factor/lymphoid enhancing factor  TCF/LEF  family [1 2]  In\\n\\nthe absence of Wnt ligands  b-catenin levels are efficiently\\nregulated by a supramolecular complex containing adenomatous\\n\\npolyposis coli  APC  axin  and glycogen synthetase kinase 3b\\n GSK3b  This complex promotes phosphorylation of b-catenin by\\ncasein kinase 1  Ck1  and GSK3b  Phosphorylated b-catenin\\nbecomes multi-ubiquitinated  Ub  and degraded by the 26S\\n\\nproteasome  The action of this complex is inhibited upon the\\n\\nbinding of Wnt to its receptors on the cell surface [1 2]  A variety\\n\\nof Wnt/b-catenin target genes have been identified  including\\nthose that regulate cell proliferation and apoptosis  thus mediating\\n\\ncancer initiation and progression [3–5]  Compelling evidence has\\n\\nindicated that there is an abnormal up-regulation of this pathway\\n\\nin tumorigenesis of many types of cancer  and that disruption of\\n\\nWnt/b-catenin signaling represents a great opportunity to develop\\nnovel drugs for cancer chemoprevention and therapy [6–8] \\n\\nExperiments performed in drosophila [9]  xenopus [10] and\\n\\nmice [11] demonstrated that the low-density lipoprotein receptor-\\n\\nrelated protein 5  LRP5 /LRP6  termed arrow in drosophila  acts\\n\\nas a co-receptor for Wnt ligands  which interact with both the\\n\\nseven transmembrane receptor of the Frizzled  Fz  family and\\n\\nLRP5/6 to activate the canonical Wnt signaling pathway  The\\n\\ncytoplasmic tails of LRP5/6  upon receptor activation by Wnt\\n\\nligand  are phosphorylated  and recruit the cytosolic scaffold\\n\\nprotein axin to the membrane  LRP6 is expressed in human\\n\\ncancer cell lines and up-regulated in human malignant tissues\\n\\n[12–16]  Studies in the past years have demonstrated that LRP6 is\\n\\na promising therapeutic target for the development of novel\\n\\nanticancer drugs [6–8 15 17 18] \\n\\nNiclosamide  trade name Niclocide  is a teniacide in the\\n\\nantihelmintic family that is especially effective against cestodes \\n\\nwhich infects humans  Niclosamide has been FDA approved for\\n\\nsuch indications and has been used in humans for nearly 50 years\\n\\n[19–21]  It is believed that niclosamide inhibits oxidative\\n\\nphosphorylation in the mitochondria of cestodes  an aerobic\\n\\nPLoS ONE | www plosone org 1 December 2011 | Volume 6 | Issue 12 | e29290\\n\\n\\n\\nmetabolism  on which many cestodes are dependent  Recently  it\\n\\nhas been demonstrated that niclosamide can downregulate\\n\\ncytosolic b-catenin expression to inhibit Wnt/b-catenin signaling\\n[22 23]  and suppress colorectal cancer growth and metastasis\\n\\n[23 24]  Since the mechanism was not well defined  we further\\n\\nstudied this  We demonstrated for the first time that niclosamide\\n\\ncan inhibit Wnt/b-catenin signaling by inducing LRP6 degrada-\\ntion  and that this activity is closely associated with its\\n\\nantiproliferative and apoptosis inducing activity \\n\\nResults\\n\\nNiclosamide blocks Wnt/b-catenin signaling induced by\\nWnt3A and LRP6 by suppressing e29290\\n\\n\\n\\nWnt/b-catenin signaling plays an important role in mammary\\ngland development and carcinogenesis [4]  Triple negative breast\\n\\ncancer  TNBC  ER  PR  and HER2-negative breast cancer  is one\\n\\nof the most difficult subtypes of breast cancer to treat due to a lack\\n\\nof a targeted therapy  Studies have demonstrated that Wnt/b-\\ncatenin signaling activation is preferentially found in TNBC and is\\n\\nassociated with a poor clinical outcome [38]  Basal-like breast\\n\\ncancer  BLBC  shares many overlapping features with BLBC \\n\\nSeveral studies have demonstrated that LRP6 is up-regulated in\\n\\nhuman TNBC or BLBC [14–16]  In mice  mammary gland\\n\\ndevelopment and MMTV-Wnt1-induced mammary tumorigene-\\n\\nsis were delayed in LRP6+/- mice [14]  while MMTV-LRP6\\n\\ntransgenic mice developed hyperplasia in their mammary glands\\n\\ndue to LRP6-mediated Wnt/b-catenin signaling [39]  Transcrip-\\ntional knockdown of LRP6 in TNBC MDA-MB-231 cells\\n\\nsignificantly decreased Wnt/b-catenin signaling  cell proliferation \\nand tumor growth in vivo [15]  In addition  it has been\\ndemonstrated that specific LRP6 antibodies were able to block\\n\\nMMTV-Wnt1 or MMTV-Wnt3 xenografts in vivo [17 18]  and\\nthat recombinant Mesd protein  an LRP6 antagonist  markedly\\n\\nsuppressed tumor growth in MMTV-Wnt1 xenograft models [15] \\n\\nMoreover  salinomycin  a breast cancer stem cell killer [40]  was\\n\\nrecently demonstrated to be an inhibitor of Wnt/b-catenin\\nsignaling by inducing LRP6 degradation [41]  In the present\\n\\nstudy  we demonstrated that niclosamide suppressed LRP6\\n\\nexpression in TNBC MDA-MB-231 cells and ER-positive breast\\n\\ncancer T-47D cells  and inhibited breast cancer cell proliferation\\n\\nwith IC50 values less than 1 mM  Our results support the concept\\nthat LRP6 is a promising therapeutic target for breast cancer\\n\\nincluding TNBC \\n\\nAccumulated evidence has demonstrated a significant role for\\n\\nWnt/b-catenin signaling in the development and progression of\\nhuman prostate cancer [3]  Although it is unclear whether LRP6 is\\n\\nup-regulated in prostate cancer  we have recently demonstrated\\n\\nthat the LRP6 antagonist Mesd markedly inhibited Wnt/b-catenin\\nsignaling in prostate cancer PC-3 cells  and suppressed PC-3 cell\\n\\nproliferation in vitro and tumor growth in vivo [42 43]  In the\\npresent study  we found niclosamide inhibited the proliferation of\\n\\nprostate cancer PC-3 and DU145 cells with IC50 values less than\\n\\n1 mM  which are comparable to those shown to suppress LRP6\\nexpression and the activities of Wnt/b-catenin signaling in\\nprostate cancer cells  Together  these findings suggest that LRP6\\n\\nis a potential therapeutic target for prostate cancer \\n\\nMutations in APC and CTNNB1 are two major factors for Wnt/\\nb-catenin signaling activation in colorectal cancers  however\\nrecent studies indicate that the levels of Wnt/b-catenin signaling\\nin colorectal cancer cells could be modulated on the cell surface\\n\\n[44–48]  In particular  Ueno et al  demonstrated that Wnt receptor\\nfrizzled-7 activates the Wnt/b-catenin pathway in colorectal\\ncancer cells despite the presence of APC or CTNNB1 mutation\\nand that frizzled-7-siRNA may be used as a therapeutic colorectal\\n\\ncancer  inhibited Wnt/b-catenin signaling and induced apoptosis\\nin human colorectal cancer cells containing downstream\\n\\nmutations [47]  The secreted frizzled-related protein  SFRP \\n\\nfamily and Wnt inhibitory factor-1  WIF-1  are secreted Wnt/b-\\ncatenin signaling antagonists that bind to Wnt ligands  and\\n\\ninterfere with Wnt-receptor interaction  It has been reported that\\n\\nloss of SFRP family expression was associated with promoter\\n\\nhypermethylation in colorectal cancer [44]  and that restoration\\n\\nof SFRP function in colorectal cancer cells attenuates Wnt/b-\\ncatenin signaling even in the presence of downstream mutations\\n\\n[45]  Similarly  He et al  reported that loss of WIF-1 expression\\n\\nwas associated with promoter hypermethylation in colorectal\\n\\ncancer  and that restoration of WIF-1 function  Wnt-1 siRNA  or\\n\\na monoclonal anti-Wnt-1 antibody induces significant apoptosis\\n\\nin colorectal cancer cells which contain downstream mutations\\n\\nand expressing Wnt-1 [46]  Very recently  it has been reported\\n\\nthat niclosamide was able to inhibit Wnt/b-catenin signaling in\\ncolorectal cancer cells  inhibited colorectal cancer growth and\\n\\nS100A4-mediated metastatic colorectal cancer [23 24]  The\\n\\ncalcium-binding protein S100A4 is a target gene of the Wnt/b-\\ncatenin pathway [49]  Future studies are required to address the\\n\\nimportance of LRP6 in colorectal cancer development and\\n\\nprogression \\n\\nThe development of FDA approved drugs that are used for\\n\\nother indications is an attractive strategy for developing new\\n\\ndrugs for cancer chemoprevention or therapy given their proven\\n\\nsafety record  Disruption of Wnt/b-catenin signaling represents a\\ngreat opportunity to determine if FDA approved drugs might\\n\\nhave potential anticancer efficacy [6–8]  Niclosamide is a\\n\\nsalicyclamide derivative and the drug of choice for the treatment\\n\\nof most tapeworm infection  Niclosamide exerts its antiparasitic\\n\\nactivity in the intestinal lumen and is poorly absorbed from the\\n\\ngastrointestinal tract [19–21]  However  in mice implanted with\\n\\nhuman colorectal cancer xenografts  orally administered niclosa-\\n\\nmide was well tolerated  achieved plasma and tumor levels\\n\\nassociated with biologic activity and led to tumor control [23] \\n\\nFurthermore  niclosamide has no significant toxicity against non-\\n\\ncancer cells in vitro and displays no obvious side effects in\\n\\nniclosamide-treated mice [23]  We demonstrate herein that\\n\\nniclosamide is a potent Wnt/b-catenin signaling inhibitor by\\ninducing LRP6 degradation in cancer cells  and displays an\\n\\nexcellent anticancer activity in vitro  Therefore  as a FDA\\n\\napproved antihelminthic drug  niclosamide will be an interesting\\n\\ncomoound to be optimized to increase its bioavailability and to be\\n\\ntested for its in vivo cancer ### Data Cleaning 
Looks like we have to clean and remove a few stop words.



```julia
#include("src/clean-data.jl")
# conver to corpus
arrayOfSdDoc = []
arrayOfStrText = []
for row in eachrow(df_full_text)
    sd,tx=bcTextmining.cleanText(row[:fullText])
    push!(arrayOfSdDoc,sd)
    push!(arrayOfStrText,tx)
end

# convert to corpus
corpus = Corpus(arrayOfSdDoc)
#standardize
standardize!(corpus, StringDocument)
#normalizes 
#stem!(corpus) # merges words like survival and survive
```

<script> <![CDATA[

(function (glob, factory) {
    // AMD support
    if (typeof define === "function" && define.amd) {
        // Define as an anonymous module
        define("Gadfly", ["Snap.svg"], function (Snap) {
            return factory(Snap);
        });
    } else {
        // Browser globals (glob is window)
        // Snap adds itself to window
        glob.Gadfly = factory(glob.Snap);
    }
}(this, function (Snap) {

var Gadfly = {};

// Get an x/y coordinate value in pixels
var xPX = function(fig, x) {
    var client_box = fig.node.getBoundingClientRect();
    return x * fig.node.viewBox.baseVal.width / client_box.width;
};

var yPX = function(fig, y) {
    var client_box = fig.node.getBoundingClientRect();
    return y * fig.node.viewBox.baseVal.height / client_box.height;
};


Snap.plugin(function (Snap, Element, Paper, global) {
    // Traverse upwards from a snap element to find and return the first
    // note with the "plotroot" class.
    Element.prototype.plotroot = function () {
        var element = this;
        while (!element.hasClass("plotroot") && element.parent() != null) {
            element = element.parent();
        }
        return element;
    };

    Element.prototype.svgroot = function () {
        var element = this;
        while (element.node.nodeName != "svg" && element.parent() != null) {
            element = element.parent();
        }
        return element;
    };

    Element.prototype.plotbounds = function () {
        var root = this.plotroot()
        var bbox = root.select(".guide.background").node.getBBox();
        return {
            x0: bbox.x,
            x1: bbox.x + bbox.width,
            y0: bbox.y,
            y1: bbox.y + bbox.height
        };
    };

    Element.prototype.plotcenter = function () {
        var root = this.plotroot()
        var bbox = root.select(".guide.background").node.getBBox();
        return {
            x: bbox.x + bbox.width / 2,
            y: bbox.y + bbox.height / 2
        };
    };

    // Emulate IE style mouseenter/mouseleave events, since Microsoft always
    // does everything right.
    // See: http://www.dynamic-tools.net/toolbox/isMouseLeaveOrEnter/
    var events = ["mouseenter", "mouseleave"];

    for (i in events) {
        (function (event_name) {
            var event_name = events[i];
            Element.prototype[event_name] = function (fn, scope) {
                if (Snap.is(fn, "function")) {
                    var fn2 = function (event) {
                        if (event.type != "mouseover" && event.type != "mouseout") {
                            return;
                        }

                        var reltg = event.relatedTarget ? event.relatedTarget :
                            event.type == "mouseout" ? event.toElement : event.fromElement;
                        while (reltg && reltg != this.node) reltg = reltg.parentNode;

                        if (reltg != this.node) {
                            return fn.apply(this, event);
                        }
                    };

                    if (event_name == "mouseenter") {
                        this.mouseover(fn2, scope);
                    } else {
                        this.mouseout(fn2, scope);
                    }
                }
                return this;
            };
        })(events[i]);
    }


    Element.prototype.mousewheel = function (fn, scope) {
        if (Snap.is(fn, "function")) {
            var el = this;
            var fn2 = function (event) {
                fn.apply(el, [event]);
            };
        }

        this.node.addEventListener(
            /Firefox/i.test(navigator.userAgent) ? "DOMMouseScroll" : "mousewheel",
            fn2);

        return this;
    };


    // Snap's attr function can be too slow for things like panning/zooming.
    // This is a function to directly update element attributes without going
    // through eve.
    Element.prototype.attribute = function(key, val) {
        if (val === undefined) {
            return this.node.getAttribute(key);
        } else {
            this.node.setAttribute(key, val);
            return this;
        }
    };

    Element.prototype.init_gadfly = function() {
        this.mouseenter(Gadfly.plot_mouseover)
            .mouseleave(Gadfly.plot_mouseout)
            .dblclick(Gadfly.plot_dblclick)
            .mousewheel(Gadfly.guide_background_scroll)
            .drag(Gadfly.guide_background_drag_onmove,
                  Gadfly.guide_background_drag_onstart,
                  Gadfly.guide_background_drag_onend);
        this.mouseenter(function (event) {
            init_pan_zoom(this.plotroot());
        });
        return this;
    };
});


// When the plot is moused over, emphasize the grid lines.
Gadfly.plot_mouseover = function(event) {
    var root = this.plotroot();

    var keyboard_zoom = function(event) {
        if (event.which == 187) { // plus
            increase_zoom_by_position(root, 0.1, true);
        } else if (event.which == 189) { // minus
            increase_zoom_by_position(root, -0.1, true);
        }
    };
    root.data("keyboard_zoom", keyboard_zoom);
    window.addEventListener("keyup", keyboard_zoom);

    var xgridlines = root.select(".xgridlines"),
        ygridlines = root.select(".ygridlines");

    xgridlines.data("unfocused_strokedash",
                    xgridlines.attribute("stroke-dasharray").replace(/(\d)(,|$)/g, "$1mm$2"));
    ygridlines.data("unfocused_strokedash",
                    ygridlines.attribute("stroke-dasharray").replace(/(\d)(,|$)/g, "$1mm$2"));

    // emphasize grid lines
    var destcolor = root.data("focused_xgrid_color");
    xgridlines.attribute("stroke-dasharray", "none")
              .selectAll("path")
              .animate({stroke: destcolor}, 250);

    destcolor = root.data("focused_ygrid_color");
    ygridlines.attribute("stroke-dasharray", "none")
              .selectAll("path")
              .animate({stroke: destcolor}, 250);

    // reveal zoom slider
    root.select(".zoomslider")
        .animate({opacity: 1.0}, 250);
};

// Reset pan and zoom on double click
Gadfly.plot_dblclick = function(event) {
  set_plot_pan_zoom(this.plotroot(), 0.0, 0.0, 1.0);
};

// Unemphasize grid lines on mouse out.
Gadfly.plot_mouseout = function(event) {
    var root = this.plotroot();

    window.removeEventListener("keyup", root.data("keyboard_zoom"));
    root.data("keyboard_zoom", undefined);

    var xgridlines = root.select(".xgridlines"),
        ygridlines = root.select(".ygridlines");

    var destcolor = root.data("unfocused_xgrid_color");

    xgridlines.attribute("stroke-dasharray", xgridlines.data("unfocused_strokedash"))
              .selectAll("path")
              .animate({stroke: destcolor}, 250);

    destcolor = root.data("unfocused_ygrid_color");
    ygridlines.attribute("stroke-dasharray", ygridlines.data("unfocused_strokedash"))
              .selectAll("path")
              .animate({stroke: destcolor}, 250);

    // hide zoom slider
    root.select(".zoomslider")
        .animate({opacity: 0.0}, 250);
};


var set_geometry_transform = function(root, tx, ty, scale) {
    var xscalable = root.hasClass("xscalable"),
        yscalable = root.hasClass("yscalable");

    var old_scale = root.data("scale");

    var xscale = xscalable ? scale : 1.0,
        yscale = yscalable ? scale : 1.0;

    tx = xscalable ? tx : 0.0;
    ty = yscalable ? ty : 0.0;

    var t = new Snap.Matrix().translate(tx, ty).scale(xscale, yscale);

    root.selectAll(".geometry, image")
        .forEach(function (element, i) {
            element.transform(t);
        });

    bounds = root.plotbounds();

    if (yscalable) {
        var xfixed_t = new Snap.Matrix().translate(0, ty).scale(1.0, yscale);
        root.selectAll(".xfixed")
            .forEach(function (element, i) {
                element.transform(xfixed_t);
            });

        root.select(".ylabels")
            .transform(xfixed_t)
            .selectAll("text")
            .forEach(function (element, i) {
                if (element.attribute("gadfly:inscale") == "true") {
                    var cx = element.asPX("x"),
                        cy = element.asPX("y");
                    var st = element.data("static_transform");
                    unscale_t = new Snap.Matrix();
                    unscale_t.scale(1, 1/scale, cx, cy).add(st);
                    element.transform(unscale_t);

                    var y = cy * scale + ty;
                    element.attr("visibility",
                        bounds.y0 <= y && y <= bounds.y1 ? "visible" : "hidden");
                }
            });
    }

    if (xscalable) {
        var yfixed_t = new Snap.Matrix().translate(tx, 0).scale(xscale, 1.0);
        var xtrans = new Snap.Matrix().translate(tx, 0);
        root.selectAll(".yfixed")
            .forEach(function (element, i) {
                element.transform(yfixed_t);
            });

        root.select(".xlabels")
            .transform(yfixed_t)
            .selectAll("text")
            .forEach(function (element, i) {
                if (element.attribute("gadfly:inscale") == "true") {
                    var cx = element.asPX("x"),
                        cy = element.asPX("y");
                    var st = element.data("static_transform");
                    unscale_t = new Snap.Matrix();
                    unscale_t.scale(1/scale, 1, cx, cy).add(st);

                    element.transform(unscale_t);

                    var x = cx * scale + tx;
                    element.attr("visibility",
                        bounds.x0 <= x && x <= bounds.x1 ? "visible" : "hidden");
                    }
            });
    }

    // we must unscale anything that is scale invariance: widths, raiduses, etc.
    var size_attribs = ["font-size"];
    var unscaled_selection = ".geometry, .geometry *";
    if (xscalable) {
        size_attribs.push("rx");
        unscaled_selection += ", .xgridlines";
    }
    if (yscalable) {
        size_attribs.push("ry");
        unscaled_selection += ", .ygridlines";
    }

    root.selectAll(unscaled_selection)
        .forEach(function (element, i) {
            // circle need special help
            if (element.node.nodeName == "circle") {
                var cx = element.attribute("cx"),
                    cy = element.attribute("cy");
                unscale_t = new Snap.Matrix().scale(1/xscale, 1/yscale,
                                                        cx, cy);
                element.transform(unscale_t);
                return;
            }

            for (i in size_attribs) {
                var key = size_attribs[i];
                var val = parseFloat(element.attribute(key));
                if (val !== undefined && val != 0 && !isNaN(val)) {
                    element.attribute(key, val * old_scale / scale);
                }
            }
        });
};


// Find the most appropriate tick scale and update label visibility.
var update_tickscale = function(root, scale, axis) {
    if (!root.hasClass(axis + "scalable")) return;

    var tickscales = root.data(axis + "tickscales");
    var best_tickscale = 1.0;
    var best_tickscale_dist = Infinity;
    for (tickscale in tickscales) {
        var dist = Math.abs(Math.log(tickscale) - Math.log(scale));
        if (dist < best_tickscale_dist) {
            best_tickscale_dist = dist;
            best_tickscale = tickscale;
        }
    }

    if (best_tickscale != root.data(axis + "tickscale")) {
        root.data(axis + "tickscale", best_tickscale);
        var mark_inscale_gridlines = function (element, i) {
            var inscale = element.attr("gadfly:scale") == best_tickscale;
            element.attribute("gadfly:inscale", inscale);
            element.attr("visibility", inscale ? "visible" : "hidden");
        };

        var mark_inscale_labels = function (element, i) {
            var inscale = element.attr("gadfly:scale") == best_tickscale;
            element.attribute("gadfly:inscale", inscale);
            element.attr("visibility", inscale ? "visible" : "hidden");
        };

        root.select("." + axis + "gridlines").selectAll("path").forEach(mark_inscale_gridlines);
        root.select("." + axis + "labels").selectAll("text").forEach(mark_inscale_labels);
    }
};


var set_plot_pan_zoom = function(root, tx, ty, scale) {
    var old_scale = root.data("scale");
    var bounds = root.plotbounds();

    var width = bounds.x1 - bounds.x0,
        height = bounds.y1 - bounds.y0;

    // compute the viewport derived from tx, ty, and scale
    var x_min = -width * scale - (scale * width - width),
        x_max = width * scale,
        y_min = -height * scale - (scale * height - height),
        y_max = height * scale;

    var x0 = bounds.x0 - scale * bounds.x0,
        y0 = bounds.y0 - scale * bounds.y0;

    var tx = Math.max(Math.min(tx - x0, x_max), x_min),
        ty = Math.max(Math.min(ty - y0, y_max), y_min);

    tx += x0;
    ty += y0;

    // when the scale change, we may need to alter which set of
    // ticks is being displayed
    if (scale != old_scale) {
        update_tickscale(root, scale, "x");
        update_tickscale(root, scale, "y");
    }

    set_geometry_transform(root, tx, ty, scale);

    root.data("scale", scale);
    root.data("tx", tx);
    root.data("ty", ty);
};


var scale_centered_translation = function(root, scale) {
    var bounds = root.plotbounds();

    var width = bounds.x1 - bounds.x0,
        height = bounds.y1 - bounds.y0;

    var tx0 = root.data("tx"),
        ty0 = root.data("ty");

    var scale0 = root.data("scale");

    // how off from center the current view is
    var xoff = tx0 - (bounds.x0 * (1 - scale0) + (width * (1 - scale0)) / 2),
        yoff = ty0 - (bounds.y0 * (1 - scale0) + (height * (1 - scale0)) / 2);

    // rescale offsets
    xoff = xoff * scale / scale0;
    yoff = yoff * scale / scale0;

    // adjust for the panel position being scaled
    var x_edge_adjust = bounds.x0 * (1 - scale),
        y_edge_adjust = bounds.y0 * (1 - scale);

    return {
        x: xoff + x_edge_adjust + (width - width * scale) / 2,
        y: yoff + y_edge_adjust + (height - height * scale) / 2
    };
};


// Initialize data for panning zooming if it isn't already.
var init_pan_zoom = function(root) {
    if (root.data("zoompan-ready")) {
        return;
    }

    // The non-scaling-stroke trick. Rather than try to correct for the
    // stroke-width when zooming, we force it to a fixed value.
    var px_per_mm = root.node.getCTM().a;

    // Drag events report deltas in pixels, which we'd like to convert to
    // millimeters.
    root.data("px_per_mm", px_per_mm);

    root.selectAll("path")
        .forEach(function (element, i) {
        sw = element.asPX("stroke-width") * px_per_mm;
        if (sw > 0) {
            element.attribute("stroke-width", sw);
            element.attribute("vector-effect", "non-scaling-stroke");
        }
    });

    // Store ticks labels original tranformation
    root.selectAll(".xlabels > text, .ylabels > text")
        .forEach(function (element, i) {
            var lm = element.transform().localMatrix;
            element.data("static_transform",
                new Snap.Matrix(lm.a, lm.b, lm.c, lm.d, lm.e, lm.f));
        });

    var xgridlines = root.select(".xgridlines");
    var ygridlines = root.select(".ygridlines");
    var xlabels = root.select(".xlabels");
    var ylabels = root.select(".ylabels");

    if (root.data("tx") === undefined) root.data("tx", 0);
    if (root.data("ty") === undefined) root.data("ty", 0);
    if (root.data("scale") === undefined) root.data("scale", 1.0);
    if (root.data("xtickscales") === undefined) {

        // index all the tick scales that are listed
        var xtickscales = {};
        var ytickscales = {};
        var add_x_tick_scales = function (element, i) {
            xtickscales[element.attribute("gadfly:scale")] = true;
        };
        var add_y_tick_scales = function (element, i) {
            ytickscales[element.attribute("gadfly:scale")] = true;
        };

        if (xgridlines) xgridlines.selectAll("path").forEach(add_x_tick_scales);
        if (ygridlines) ygridlines.selectAll("path").forEach(add_y_tick_scales);
        if (xlabels) xlabels.selectAll("text").forEach(add_x_tick_scales);
        if (ylabels) ylabels.selectAll("text").forEach(add_y_tick_scales);

        root.data("xtickscales", xtickscales);
        root.data("ytickscales", ytickscales);
        root.data("xtickscale", 1.0);
    }

    var min_scale = 1.0, max_scale = 1.0;
    for (scale in xtickscales) {
        min_scale = Math.min(min_scale, scale);
        max_scale = Math.max(max_scale, scale);
    }
    for (scale in ytickscales) {
        min_scale = Math.min(min_scale, scale);
        max_scale = Math.max(max_scale, scale);
    }
    root.data("min_scale", min_scale);
    root.data("max_scale", max_scale);

    // store the original positions of labels
    if (xlabels) {
        xlabels.selectAll("text")
               .forEach(function (element, i) {
                   element.data("x", element.asPX("x"));
               });
    }

    if (ylabels) {
        ylabels.selectAll("text")
               .forEach(function (element, i) {
                   element.data("y", element.asPX("y"));
               });
    }

    // mark grid lines and ticks as in or out of scale.
    var mark_inscale = function (element, i) {
        element.attribute("gadfly:inscale", element.attribute("gadfly:scale") == 1.0);
    };

    if (xgridlines) xgridlines.selectAll("path").forEach(mark_inscale);
    if (ygridlines) ygridlines.selectAll("path").forEach(mark_inscale);
    if (xlabels) xlabels.selectAll("text").forEach(mark_inscale);
    if (ylabels) ylabels.selectAll("text").forEach(mark_inscale);

    // figure out the upper ond lower bounds on panning using the maximum
    // and minum grid lines
    var bounds = root.plotbounds();
    var pan_bounds = {
        x0: 0.0,
        y0: 0.0,
        x1: 0.0,
        y1: 0.0
    };

    if (xgridlines) {
        xgridlines
            .selectAll("path")
            .forEach(function (element, i) {
                if (element.attribute("gadfly:inscale") == "true") {
                    var bbox = element.node.getBBox();
                    if (bounds.x1 - bbox.x < pan_bounds.x0) {
                        pan_bounds.x0 = bounds.x1 - bbox.x;
                    }
                    if (bounds.x0 - bbox.x > pan_bounds.x1) {
                        pan_bounds.x1 = bounds.x0 - bbox.x;
                    }
                    element.attr("visibility", "visible");
                }
            });
    }

    if (ygridlines) {
        ygridlines
            .selectAll("path")
            .forEach(function (element, i) {
                if (element.attribute("gadfly:inscale") == "true") {
                    var bbox = element.node.getBBox();
                    if (bounds.y1 - bbox.y < pan_bounds.y0) {
                        pan_bounds.y0 = bounds.y1 - bbox.y;
                    }
                    if (bounds.y0 - bbox.y > pan_bounds.y1) {
                        pan_bounds.y1 = bounds.y0 - bbox.y;
                    }
                    element.attr("visibility", "visible");
                }
            });
    }

    // nudge these values a little
    pan_bounds.x0 -= 5;
    pan_bounds.x1 += 5;
    pan_bounds.y0 -= 5;
    pan_bounds.y1 += 5;
    root.data("pan_bounds", pan_bounds);

    root.data("zoompan-ready", true)
};


// drag actions, i.e. zooming and panning
var pan_action = {
    start: function(root, x, y, event) {
        root.data("dx", 0);
        root.data("dy", 0);
        root.data("tx0", root.data("tx"));
        root.data("ty0", root.data("ty"));
    },
    update: function(root, dx, dy, x, y, event) {
        var px_per_mm = root.data("px_per_mm");
        dx /= px_per_mm;
        dy /= px_per_mm;

        var tx0 = root.data("tx"),
            ty0 = root.data("ty");

        var dx0 = root.data("dx"),
            dy0 = root.data("dy");

        root.data("dx", dx);
        root.data("dy", dy);

        dx = dx - dx0;
        dy = dy - dy0;

        var tx = tx0 + dx,
            ty = ty0 + dy;

        set_plot_pan_zoom(root, tx, ty, root.data("scale"));
    },
    end: function(root, event) {

    },
    cancel: function(root) {
        set_plot_pan_zoom(root, root.data("tx0"), root.data("ty0"), root.data("scale"));
    }
};

var zoom_box;
var zoom_action = {
    start: function(root, x, y, event) {
        var bounds = root.plotbounds();
        var width = bounds.x1 - bounds.x0,
            height = bounds.y1 - bounds.y0;
        var ratio = width / height;
        var xscalable = root.hasClass("xscalable"),
            yscalable = root.hasClass("yscalable");
        var px_per_mm = root.data("px_per_mm");
        x = xscalable ? x / px_per_mm : bounds.x0;
        y = yscalable ? y / px_per_mm : bounds.y0;
        var w = xscalable ? 0 : width;
        var h = yscalable ? 0 : height;
        zoom_box = root.rect(x, y, w, h).attr({
            "fill": "#000",
            "opacity": 0.25
        });
        zoom_box.data("ratio", ratio);
    },
    update: function(root, dx, dy, x, y, event) {
        var xscalable = root.hasClass("xscalable"),
            yscalable = root.hasClass("yscalable");
        var px_per_mm = root.data("px_per_mm");
        var bounds = root.plotbounds();
        if (yscalable) {
            y /= px_per_mm;
            y = Math.max(bounds.y0, y);
            y = Math.min(bounds.y1, y);
        } else {
            y = bounds.y1;
        }
        if (xscalable) {
            x /= px_per_mm;
            x = Math.max(bounds.x0, x);
            x = Math.min(bounds.x1, x);
        } else {
            x = bounds.x1;
        }

        dx = x - zoom_box.attr("x");
        dy = y - zoom_box.attr("y");
        if (xscalable && yscalable) {
            var ratio = zoom_box.data("ratio");
            var width = Math.min(Math.abs(dx), ratio * Math.abs(dy));
            var height = Math.min(Math.abs(dy), Math.abs(dx) / ratio);
            dx = width * dx / Math.abs(dx);
            dy = height * dy / Math.abs(dy);
        }
        var xoffset = 0,
            yoffset = 0;
        if (dx < 0) {
            xoffset = dx;
            dx = -1 * dx;
        }
        if (dy < 0) {
            yoffset = dy;
            dy = -1 * dy;
        }
        if (isNaN(dy)) {
            dy = 0.0;
        }
        if (isNaN(dx)) {
            dx = 0.0;
        }
        zoom_box.transform("T" + xoffset + "," + yoffset);
        zoom_box.attr("width", dx);
        zoom_box.attr("height", dy);
    },
    end: function(root, event) {
        var xscalable = root.hasClass("xscalable"),
            yscalable = root.hasClass("yscalable");
        var zoom_bounds = zoom_box.getBBox();
        if (zoom_bounds.width * zoom_bounds.height <= 0) {
            return;
        }
        var plot_bounds = root.plotbounds();
        var zoom_factor = 1.0;
        if (yscalable) {
            zoom_factor = (plot_bounds.y1 - plot_bounds.y0) / zoom_bounds.height;
        } else {
            zoom_factor = (plot_bounds.x1 - plot_bounds.x0) / zoom_bounds.width;
        }
        var tx = (root.data("tx") - zoom_bounds.x) * zoom_factor + plot_bounds.x0,
            ty = (root.data("ty") - zoom_bounds.y) * zoom_factor + plot_bounds.y0;
        set_plot_pan_zoom(root, tx, ty, root.data("scale") * zoom_factor);
        zoom_box.remove();
    },
    cancel: function(root) {
        zoom_box.remove();
    }
};


Gadfly.guide_background_drag_onstart = function(x, y, event) {
    var root = this.plotroot();
    var scalable = root.hasClass("xscalable") || root.hasClass("yscalable");
    var zoomable = !event.altKey && !event.ctrlKey && event.shiftKey && scalable;
    var panable = !event.altKey && !event.ctrlKey && !event.shiftKey && scalable;
    var drag_action = zoomable ? zoom_action :
                      panable  ? pan_action :
                                 undefined;
    root.data("drag_action", drag_action);
    if (drag_action) {
        var cancel_drag_action = function(event) {
            if (event.which == 27) { // esc key
                drag_action.cancel(root);
                root.data("drag_action", undefined);
            }
        };
        window.addEventListener("keyup", cancel_drag_action);
        root.data("cancel_drag_action", cancel_drag_action);
        drag_action.start(root, x, y, event);
    }
};


Gadfly.guide_background_drag_onmove = function(dx, dy, x, y, event) {
    var root = this.plotroot();
    var drag_action = root.data("drag_action");
    if (drag_action) {
        drag_action.update(root, dx, dy, x, y, event);
    }
};


Gadfly.guide_background_drag_onend = function(event) {
    var root = this.plotroot();
    window.removeEventListener("keyup", root.data("cancel_drag_action"));
    root.data("cancel_drag_action", undefined);
    var drag_action = root.data("drag_action");
    if (drag_action) {
        drag_action.end(root, event);
    }
    root.data("drag_action", undefined);
};


Gadfly.guide_background_scroll = function(event) {
    if (event.shiftKey) {
        increase_zoom_by_position(this.plotroot(), 0.001 * event.wheelDelta);
        event.preventDefault();
    }
};


Gadfly.zoomslider_button_mouseover = function(event) {
    this.select(".button_logo")
         .animate({fill: this.data("mouseover_color")}, 100);
};


Gadfly.zoomslider_button_mouseout = function(event) {
     this.select(".button_logo")
         .animate({fill: this.data("mouseout_color")}, 100);
};


Gadfly.zoomslider_zoomout_click = function(event) {
    increase_zoom_by_position(this.plotroot(), -0.1, true);
};


Gadfly.zoomslider_zoomin_click = function(event) {
    increase_zoom_by_position(this.plotroot(), 0.1, true);
};


Gadfly.zoomslider_track_click = function(event) {
    // TODO
};


// Map slider position x to scale y using the function y = a*exp(b*x)+c.
// The constants a, b, and c are solved using the constraint that the function
// should go through the points (0; min_scale), (0.5; 1), and (1; max_scale).
var scale_from_slider_position = function(position, min_scale, max_scale) {
    var a = (1 - 2 * min_scale + min_scale * min_scale) / (min_scale + max_scale - 2),
        b = 2 * Math.log((max_scale - 1) / (1 - min_scale)),
        c = (min_scale * max_scale - 1) / (min_scale + max_scale - 2);
    return a * Math.exp(b * position) + c;
}

// inverse of scale_from_slider_position
var slider_position_from_scale = function(scale, min_scale, max_scale) {
    var a = (1 - 2 * min_scale + min_scale * min_scale) / (min_scale + max_scale - 2),
        b = 2 * Math.log((max_scale - 1) / (1 - min_scale)),
        c = (min_scale * max_scale - 1) / (min_scale + max_scale - 2);
    return 1 / b * Math.log((scale - c) / a);
}

var increase_zoom_by_position = function(root, delta_position, animate) {
    var scale = root.data("scale"),
        min_scale = root.data("min_scale"),
        max_scale = root.data("max_scale");
    var position = slider_position_from_scale(scale, min_scale, max_scale);
    position += delta_position;
    scale = scale_from_slider_position(position, min_scale, max_scale);
    set_zoom(root, scale, animate);
}

var set_zoom = function(root, scale, animate) {
    var min_scale = root.data("min_scale"),
        max_scale = root.data("max_scale"),
        old_scale = root.data("scale");
    var new_scale = Math.max(min_scale, Math.min(scale, max_scale));
    if (animate) {
        Snap.animate(
            old_scale,
            new_scale,
            function (new_scale) {
                update_plot_scale(root, new_scale);
            },
            200);
    } else {
        update_plot_scale(root, new_scale);
    }
}


var update_plot_scale = function(root, new_scale) {
    var trans = scale_centered_translation(root, new_scale);
    set_plot_pan_zoom(root, trans.x, trans.y, new_scale);

    root.selectAll(".zoomslider_thumb")
        .forEach(function (element, i) {
            var min_pos = element.data("min_pos"),
                max_pos = element.data("max_pos"),
                min_scale = root.data("min_scale"),
                max_scale = root.data("max_scale");
            var xmid = (min_pos + max_pos) / 2;
            var xpos = slider_position_from_scale(new_scale, min_scale, max_scale);
            element.transform(new Snap.Matrix().translate(
                Math.max(min_pos, Math.min(
                         max_pos, min_pos + (max_pos - min_pos) * xpos)) - xmid, 0));
    });
};


Gadfly.zoomslider_thumb_dragmove = function(dx, dy, x, y, event) {
    var root = this.plotroot();
    var min_pos = this.data("min_pos"),
        max_pos = this.data("max_pos"),
        min_scale = root.data("min_scale"),
        max_scale = root.data("max_scale"),
        old_scale = root.data("old_scale");

    var px_per_mm = root.data("px_per_mm");
    dx /= px_per_mm;
    dy /= px_per_mm;

    var xmid = (min_pos + max_pos) / 2;
    var xpos = slider_position_from_scale(old_scale, min_scale, max_scale) +
                   dx / (max_pos - min_pos);

    // compute the new scale
    var new_scale = scale_from_slider_position(xpos, min_scale, max_scale);
    new_scale = Math.min(max_scale, Math.max(min_scale, new_scale));

    update_plot_scale(root, new_scale);
    event.stopPropagation();
};


Gadfly.zoomslider_thumb_dragstart = function(x, y, event) {
    this.animate({fill: this.data("mouseover_color")}, 100);
    var root = this.plotroot();

    // keep track of what the scale was when we started dragging
    root.data("old_scale", root.data("scale"));
    event.stopPropagation();
};


Gadfly.zoomslider_thumb_dragend = function(event) {
    this.animate({fill: this.data("mouseout_color")}, 100);
    event.stopPropagation();
};


var toggle_color_class = function(root, color_class, ison) {
    var guides = root.selectAll(".guide." + color_class + ",.guide ." + color_class);
    var geoms = root.selectAll(".geometry." + color_class + ",.geometry ." + color_class);
    if (ison) {
        guides.animate({opacity: 0.5}, 250);
        geoms.animate({opacity: 0.0}, 250);
    } else {
        guides.animate({opacity: 1.0}, 250);
        geoms.animate({opacity: 1.0}, 250);
    }
};


Gadfly.colorkey_swatch_click = function(event) {
    var root = this.plotroot();
    var color_class = this.data("color_class");

    if (event.shiftKey) {
        root.selectAll(".colorkey text")
            .forEach(function (element) {
                var other_color_class = element.data("color_class");
                if (other_color_class != color_class) {
                    toggle_color_class(root, other_color_class,
                                       element.attr("opacity") == 1.0);
                }
            });
    } else {
        toggle_color_class(root, color_class, this.attr("opacity") == 1.0);
    }
};


return Gadfly;
